text: What is embodied cognition?

It’s actually the idea that the body and
the mind work together and that our bodily

feelings, our physical sensations influence
our thoughts, our decisions, our behaviors,

our emotions and what is more important often
without our words.

In other words, the temperature of the things
we touch, the texture of the things we touch,
the colors we see.

Everything that we feel through our senses
affect us not in the most obvious way but
in ways that we could not have imagined.

I know that most people don’t realize how
major effect they have on our life.

And it is important because if you walk in
the street or if you touch something or the

way I’m sitting now on the sofa or hard
chair or the distance between me and the camera.

All these influence the way people perceive
me and I perceive others.
And as a consequence the way we behave.

And once we know it we can be less manipulated
by these physical experiences and maybe come

to more judgments that are based on the real
issue rather than on things which are actually
irrelevant in a way.
So we all know that we use metaphors.
We say somebody’s a warm person.
I had a heavy decision.
I had a hard day, a rough day.
We had a smooth sailing.
If you notice what do we do?

We take a concrete concept and we use it to
describe more abstract concepts.

We say somebody’s a warm person so we take
a concrete concept such as a warm temperature

and to discard a personality which is more
an abstract concept.

Or we say I had a rough day, we use the temperature
rough that we all know what it is to describe
something more abstract.
Metaphors are not just figures of speech.
They’re more than that.

They are part of the process of understanding
a concept in our cognitions.

And I can start with temperature to show this
effect and then I’ll go along all the other
senses.
Temperature.
Let’s start with temperature.

We touch warm and hot and cold things all
the time.
We hold our coffee or iced coffee, beverages.
We take a bath or shower.
We go to the swimming pool.
We touch all the time hot and cold things.
How do they affect us.

So as I said before we use the term a warm
personality, warm hearted, et cetera.

Two researchers from Yale University, Williams
and Barghe, decided to examine what is the

meaning of this metaphor for whether it has
more than just a figure of speech.

So what they did was they invited participants
to their laboratory and when each participant

came to the lab it was accompanied by an experimenter
to the fourth floor in the elevator.

What the participants didn’t know is that
the experiment actually started in the elevator

because the experimenter had her hands full
and at a certain point she asked each participant

could you hold my cup of coffee for a minute
for me while I’m writing your name.

Now for half of the participants she handed
a cold cup of coffee, an iced coffee.

For the other half she handed a warm cup of
coffee.
That’s all.
Then she took her cup of coffee back.

Then they came to the lab immediately after
that and they were asked to judge a person
they never knew about certain characteristics.

The amazing result was that those who held
a cold cup of coffee in the elevator judged

that person as less warmer considered personality
than those who held a warm cup of coffee.

In other words, those who held a warm cup
of coffee judged that person as a nicer person,

a friendlier, warm hearted person compared
to those who held a cold cup of coffee.

Now these researchers wanted to find out whether
it’s not only affecting judgment of others
but actual behavior.

So in a second experiment they told participants
that they were participating in a marketing

study where they had to hold for a few minutes
a therapeutic pad.

Have of the subjects held a warm therapeutic
pad, the other half a cold therapeutic pad.

And then were was some questions about a product
as if it was a marketing study.

And then they were asked – were offered
as a reward for their participation either

– to choose either a gift for themselves
or a gift for a friend.

Those who held a warm therapeutic pad chose
more often a gift for a friend than a gift

for themselves and more often chose a, but
more important they chose more often a gift

for a friend than those who held a cold therapeutic
pad.
In other words, it affected their generosity.

If I take all these together that just the
touch of something warm or cold affected the

way we perceive others, the way we behave
and the way we trust others.

Think about how these implications, so many
implications in real life situations.

When you interact whether it’s a business
negotiation or whether you interact with your

friends, with your family, with your children,
with your spouse, with your boss, whatever.

You definitely want that the other person
would perceive you as a nicer person.

You definitely want that person to be more
generous and trust you more.
